brief: Startup School is a free online program and global community of founders.

stems.text: If there is only one thing that Kevin wants us audience to take away, what would that be?

choices.A: For every company that gets to YC, there's probably another company that's just as good to them out there but they messed up on the application.
choices.B: Average investors always try to poke holes on your idea, while good investors do it the other way around
choices.C: Be clear and concise when you try to pitch your startup
choices.D: A best application make the investor feel like "Fuck, I wanna join their company"

explains.text: Here is the ending of the talk, "All right, I'm pretty much here at the end. The best way to help me, and I would love for you to help me, is to be clear and concise. Thank you very much."

stems.text: Just to remind you the things to avoid that makes your idea muddy:
1. Complexity, a simple idea is one idea that doesn't fold, and a complex idea are ideas intertwined.
2. Mystery, use any words that make the idea harder to understand
3. Ignorable, avoid marketing speak, MBA speak and buzzwords
4. Reproducible, listeners can imagine the idea in their minds
Which of the following idea(s) are legible

choices.A: "We are going to transform the relationship between individuals and information."
choices.B: "Synchronize files across your or your team's computers."
choices.C: "The first online marketplace that lets travelers book rooms with locals, instead of hotels."
choices.D: "Build X-ray vision for soldiers and first responders"
choices.E: "Learn and sharing knowledge about Data Science and Artificial Intelligence"

explains.text: Just apply the four things to the choices, complexity, mystery, ignorable, reproducible.

elements.brief: YC Partner Eric Migicovsky shares a framework for asking questions and collecting feedback from your users.

stems.text: If you're the CEO, and want to know how users feel about your ideas or products, what should you do?

choices.A: Hire a professional product manager to help you collect user feedbacks
choices.B: Ask salespeople to do that for you

explains.text: If you are the CEO, it is your job. It is in your job description to talk to customers.

You want to make sure that the founders and the core members of your company are the ones who develop the skills for talking to users. So, you do not have to hire someone like that to be the go-between.

stems.text: What are the typical mistakes that founders make when talking to users?

choices.A: Take users as investors, and describe what the products will be in the future
choices.B: Talk based on assumptions, and ask questions like 'would you like it if we do X'
choices.C: Spend a lot of time talking instead of listening
choices.D: Take notes when talking and bring back facts

explains.text: The three mistakes are 'pitching the product', 'talk about hypotheticals' and 'spend a lot of time talking'

stems.text: Just to remind you the five great questions that everyone can ask during their early customer interviews
1. What is the hardest part about doing the thing that you're trying to solve?
2. Tell me about the last time that you encountered this problem.
3. Why was this (solving the problem) hard?
4. What, if anything, have you done to try to solve this problem?
5. What don't you love about the solutions that you've already tried?
As founder(s), when you ask the five questions in interviews, what information are you trying to extract?

choices.A: Some aspects about the problem you didn't notice
choices.B: If users feel painful about the problem
choices.C: How do they like your product
choices.D: How often do your users encounter this problem
choices.E: Understand how you can market your product
choices.F: More information about your competitors out there
choices.G: What features do users want of your product

explains.text: Basically the purpose is to know more facts about the problem. The exact answers can be directly found in the original material.
click here to visit the source

stems.text: If it's hard for you to find potential users, what hacks can you do?

choices.A: Send emails to a broad range of people
choices.B: If the product also serves you, test your interview strategy on yourself
choices.C: Show up directly in front of your users and ask for an interview
choices.D: Pitch your idea to your friends and family

explains.text: A. Randomly sending emails is considered to be an easy thing to do
B. It's another way of "Eating your own dog food"
C & E. Eric mentioned this directly in the talk.
D. Don't pitch idea to your users

stems.text: What statement(s) are true about users with highest potential

choices.B: The problem comes to them regularly
choices.C: They have control over the budget

explains.text: These are the three facts Eric mentioned in the talk, that help founders to prioritize customers

stems.text: What stages you can benefit from user interviews?

choices.C: After launch and before product-market fit

explains.text: Talking to users is useful at pretty much all stages of your company, especially the first three.

stems.text: Which is Paul Graham's definition for product-market fit

choices.A: "When you've made something that people want"
choices.B: "When the product is just being pulled out of you. When you no longer have to push the product on customers, they're just pulling it from you."
choices.C: "When 40% or more of your user base reports that they would be very disappointed if your product went away on a weekly basis"

explains.text: This is a boring question though.
